irrelevant.action_point:
E.1 Liabilities and Capital receiving a 100 per cent ASF Factor
Liabilities and capital instruments receiving a 100 per cent ASF factor comprise:
(1) The total amount of regulatory capital, before the application of capital deductions, as defined in Reserve Bank of India (Small Finance Banks – Prudential Norms on Capital Adequacy) Directions, 2025, excluding the proportion of Tier 2 instruments with residual maturity of less than one year.
(2) The total amount of any capital instrument not included in (1) above that has an effective residual maturity of one year or more but excluding any instruments with explicit or embedded options that, if exercised, would reduce the expected maturity to less than one year.
(3) The total amount of secured and unsecured borrowings and liabilities (including term deposits) with effective residual maturities of one year or more. Cash flows due before the one year horizon but arising from liabilities with a final maturity greater than one year shall not qualify for the 100 per cent ASF factor.
Explanation: The term deposits (TDs) receiving 100 per cent ASF shall include TDs which cannot be withdrawn early without a significant penalty. For arriving at effective residual maturity of borrowings and liabilities, a bank shall consider the possibilities of early withdrawal due to ‘call options’, either embedded or explicit.

irrelevant.action_point:
B.1 Risk weights
27. On balance sheet assets - In these Directions, degrees of credit risk expressed as percentage weightages have been assigned to balance sheet assets. Hence, the value of each asset / item requires to be multiplied by the relevant risk weights to arrive at risk adjusted value of assets. The aggregate shall be taken into account for reckoning the minimum capital ratio. The risk weighted asset shall be calculated as the weighted aggregate of funded items as detailed hereunder:
(i) Cash shall have a risk weightage of 0 per cent.
(ii) Bank balances and claims on banks including fixed deposits and certificates of deposits shall have a risk weightage of 20 per cent.
(iii) Investments in Central Government and State Government Securities shall have a risk weightage of 0 per cent.
(iii) Investments in Bonds of banks shall have a risk weightage of 20 per cent.
(iii) Investments in Fixed deposits / certificates of deposits / bonds of public financial institutions shall have a risk weightage of 100 per cent.
(iii) Investments in Shares of all companies (where shares of corporates can be acquired only in satisfaction of debt) and debentures / bonds / commercial papers of all companies and units of debt oriented / money market mutual funds shall have a risk weightage of 100 per cent.
(iv) Current Assets/Other Financial Assets - Loans and advances shall have a risk weightage of 100 per cent.
(iv) Current Assets/Other Financial Assets - Loans to staff, if fully covered by superannuities, benefits & mortgage of flats / houses shall have a risk weightage of 20 per cent.
(iv) Current Assets/Other Financial Assets - Other loans to staff shall have a risk weightage of 100 per cent.
(iv) Current Assets/Other Financial Assets - Other secured loans and advances shall have a risk weightage of 100 per cent.
(iv) Current Assets/Other Financial Assets - Others (including net stock on hire, bills purchased and discounted, etc.) shall have a risk weightage of 100 per cent.
(v) Fixed Assets (net of depreciation) - Assets leased out (net book value) shall have a risk weightage of 100 per cent.
(v) Fixed Assets (net of depreciation) - Premises shall have a risk weightage of 100 per cent.
(v) Fixed Assets (net of depreciation) - Furniture & Fixtures shall have a risk weightage of 100 per cent.
(v) Fixed Assets (net of depreciation) - Other fixed assets shall have a risk weightage of 100 per cent.
(vi) Other Assets - Income tax deducted at source (net of provision) shall have a risk weightage of 0 per cent.
(vi) Other Assets - Advance tax paid (net of provision) shall have a risk weightage of 0 per cent.
(vi) Other Assets - Interest due on Government securities shall have a risk weightage of 0 per cent.
(vi) Other Assets - Others (including ROU assets) shall have a risk weightage of 100 per cent.

In case the depositor does not exercise his option of choosing the term for renewal, NBFCs shall renew the same for a term equal to the original term. (2) No new receipt shall be issued. However, suitable note shall be made regarding renewal in the deposit ledger. (3) Renewal of deposit shall be advised by registered letter / speed post / courier service to the concerned Government department under advice to the depositor. In the advice to the depositor, the rate of interest at which the deposit is renewed shall also be mentioned. (4) If overdue period does not exceed 14 days on the date of receipt of the request letter, renewal shall be done from the date of maturity. If it exceeds 14 days, NBFCs shall pay interest for the overdue period as per the policy adopted by them, and keep it in a separate interest free sub-account which shall be released when the original fixed deposit is released.

(22) 'Other Demand and Time Liabilities (ODTL)' shall include the following:
(i) Interest accrued on deposits, bills payable, unpaid dividends, suspense account balances representing amounts due to other banks or public, net credit balances in branch adjustment account, and any amounts due to the banking system which are not in the nature of deposits or borrowing.
(ii) The balance outstanding in the blocked account pertaining to segregated outstanding credit entries for more than five years in inter-branch adjustment account, the margin money on bills purchased / discounted and gold borrowed by banks from abroad. Explanation:
(a) Such liabilities may arise due to items like collection of bills on behalf of other banks, interest due to other banks and so on. 'Other Demand and Time Liabilities (ODTL)' shall include the following:
(i) Interest accrued on deposits, bills payable, unpaid dividends, suspense account balances representing amounts due to other banks or public, net credit balances in branch adjustment account, and any amounts due to the banking system which are not in the nature of deposits or borrowing.
(ii) The balance outstanding in the blocked account pertaining to segregated outstanding credit entries for more than five years in inter-branch adjustment account, the margin money on bills purchased / discounted and gold borrowed by banks from abroad. The conversion rate of gold into rupees is to be done by crossing the London AM fixing for Gold/USD rate with the rupee-dollar reference rate announced by Financial Benchmarks India Private Limited (FBIL).
(iii) Borrowings through instruments qualifying for Upper Tier 2 and Tier 2 capital.
Explanation:
(a) Such liabilities may arise due to items like collection of bills on behalf of other banks, interest due to other banks and so on. If a bank cannot segregate the liabilities to the banking system from the total of ODTL, the entire ODTL may be shown against item II(c) 'Other Demand and Time Liabilities' of the Return in Form 'A'.
(b) Cash collaterals received under collateralised derivative transactions should be included in the bank's NDTL for the purpose of reserve requirements as these are in the nature of ‘outside liabilities'. Interest accrued on deposits should be calculated on each reporting fortnight (as per the interest calculation methods applicable to various types of accounts) so that the bank's liability in this regard is fairly reflected in the total NDTL of the same fortnightly return.

For claim related rectification, a bank must use Form C and provide the following details:

**A. Details of actual, correct and excess claim:**
- The bank must report the 'Actual Claim', 'Correct Claim', and 'Excess Claim' with the 'Date of claim paid'.
- This information must be broken down into 'Interest bearing', 'Non-Interest bearing', 'Other credits', and 'Total' categories.
- For 'Interest bearing', the details required are 'No. of Accounts', 'Principal Amount', and 'Interest Paid'.
- For 'Non-Interest bearing' and 'Other credits', the details required are 'No. of Accounts' and 'Amounts'.
- The 'Total' column must sum up the 'No. of Accounts' and 'Amounts' across all categories.

**B. Details of Excess Claim sent with regular deposit in current month:**
- The bank must report the 'Regular deposit for current month', the 'Excess Claim returned back', and the 'Total Deposit' with the 'Date of deposit'.
- This information must be broken down into 'Interest bearing', 'Non-Interest bearing', 'Other credits', and 'Total' categories, specifying the 'No. of Accounts' and 'Amounts' for each.
- The interest paid in the excess claim (from section A) must be clubbed with the 'Excess claim returned back' in the 'Interest Bearing amount' (in section B).

**Reason for Rectification:**
- The bank must provide a reason for the rectification.

**Authorization and Certification:**
- The form must be signed by two authorized signatories, including their names and designations, with the bank's stamp.
- The form must include a certificate signed by the bank’s Internal/Concurrent Auditors with their stamp, stating: 'Details given above are true as per the records of the bank and verified by me and found to be correct.'

irrelevant.action_point:
For a non-banking financial company not being a 'problem Non-Banking Financial Company', in order to meet certain expenses of an emergent nature, subject to the satisfaction of the NBFC concerned about such circumstances—
20.1. 'Tiny deposits' may prematurely be paid to individual depositors, at the request of the depositor, before the expiry of three months from the date of acceptance of such deposits, in entirety, without interest;
20.2. In case of other public deposits, not more than fifty per cent of the amount of the principal sum of deposit or ₹5 lakh, whichever is lower, may be prematurely paid to individual depositors, at the request of the depositors, before the expiry of three months from the date of acceptance of such deposits, without interest; the remaining amount with interest at the contracted rate shall be governed by the provisions of the extant directions as applicable for public deposits;
Provided that in cases of critical illness, hundred per cent of the amount of the principal sum of deposit, may be prematurely paid to individual depositors, at the request of the depositors, before the expiry of three months from the date of acceptance of such deposits, without interest.
Explanation:
a. For this purpose, expenses of an emergent nature include medical emergency or expenses due to natural calamities/ disaster as notified by the concerned Government/ authority.
b. For the definition of ‘Critical illness', NBFCs shall be guided by the IRDAI (Health Insurance) Regulations, 2016 and the guidelines issued thereunder, as amended from time to time.
c. The amount as per these provisions shall also apply to the existing deposit contracts wherein the individual depositor does not have a right to premature withdrawal of the deposit before the expiry of three months.
For the purpose of this directive, a 'problem non-banking financial company' means a non-banking financial company which - (i) has refused or failed to meet within five working days any lawful demand for repayment of the matured public deposits; or (ii) intimates the CLB under section 58AA of the Companies Act, 1956, about its default to a small depositor in repayment of any public deposit or part thereof or any interest thereupon; or (iii) approaches the Bank for withdrawal of the liquid asset securities to meet its deposit obligations; or (iv) approaches the Bank for any relief or relaxation or exemption from the provisions of these Directions or from that of Master Direction – Reserve Bank of India (Non-Banking Financial Company – Scale Based Regulation) Directions, 2023 for avoiding default in meeting public deposit or other obligations; or (v) has been identified by the Bank to be a problem non-banking financial company either suo moto or based on the complaints from the depositors about non-repayment of public deposits or on complaints from the company's lenders about non-payment of dues. A ‘Tiny deposit' means the aggregate amount of public deposits not exceeding ₹10,000/- standing in the name of the sole or the first named depositor in the same capacity in all the branches of the non-banking financial company.

When completing FORM VIII, Payments Banks must report their financial position, rounded off to the nearest thousand rupees, by structuring the data and performing calculations as follows:
PART - A
I. Report Liabilities in India to the Banking System (excluding any loan taken by a Regional Rural Bank from its sponsor Bank), broken down by (a) Demand Liabilities and (b) Time Liabilities.
II. Report Liabilities in India to others (excluding borrowings from the Reserve Bank, Export-Import Bank of India and National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development), broken down by (a) Demand Liabilities and (b) Time Liabilities.
III. Report Cash in hand.
IV. Report Balances in current account with the Reserve Bank.
V. Report Assets in India with the Banking System, broken down by balances in current/other accounts, money at call, advances, and other assets.
VI. Calculate and report 'Net balance in current accounts' as V(a)(i) - I(a)(i).
VII. Calculate and report 'Net liabilities for the purpose of Section 18 and 24 of the Banking Regulation Act, 1949' as (I-V)+II if (I-V) is a plus figure, or as II only if (I-V) is a minus figure.
PART - C
XI. Report the 'Minimum amount of assets required to be maintained under Section 24 of the Banking Regulation Act, 1949', based on the percentage of net liabilities (VII) as on the last Friday of the second preceding fortnight as specified by the Reserve Bank.
XII. Report the (a) Balance required to be maintained by a scheduled bank under Section 42 of the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934, (b) Balance actually maintained, and (c) Excess of (b) over (a).
XIII. Report 'Assets actually maintained' by totaling: (a) Amount in cash deposited with the Reserve Bank by a banking company incorporated outside India under Section 11(2) of the Banking Regulation Act, 1949, (b) Cash in hand, (c) Excess balance with the Reserve Bank as per XII(c), (d) Net balance in current account as per VI, (e) Balances maintained by a Regional Rural Bank in call or fixed deposit with its Sponsor Bank, (f) Gold valued at a price not exceeding the current market price, (g) Unencumbered approved securities valued on the basis of the method of valuation determined by the Reserve Bank, and (h) Approved securities deposited with the Reserve Bank by a banking company incorporated outside India under section 11(2) of the Banking Regulation Act, 1949.

The bank may be allowed an appropriate timeline to comply with the limits. Failure to comply within the given timeline would result in deduction of the excess exposure amount from Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) capital of the bank until the limits are restored. A bank having negative net worth may approach the concerned Regional Office of RBI with specific proposal for financial restructuring after it has been approved by its Board, provided that the proposal conforms to the following norms:
(1) No conversion of deposits into equity shall be permitted in respect of depositors holding deposits in the bank up to the insurance coverage limit specified by the Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation (DICGC) from time to time;
(2) A portion of the deposits of individual depositors exceeding the DICGC insurance coverage limit may be converted into equity. Similarly, a portion of the deposits of institutional depositors may be converted into Innovative Perpetual Debt Instruments (IPDIs), which are eligible for inclusion in Tier I capital. Issuance of such IPDIs shall be governed by the terms and conditions set out in Reserve Bank of India (Urban Co-operative Banks – Prudential Norms on Capital Adequacy) Directions, 2025. Provided that, the conversion of deposits into equity and / or IPDI shall be subject to consent of the depositors.
(3) Post-restructuring, no shares (equities) shall be redeemed until the bank achieves a CRAR as per regulatory requirement.
(4) The proportion of deposits converted into equity or IPDI shall be such that the net worth of the bank turns positive after the financial restructuring. Provided that, this requirement regarding positive net worth shall not apply if the depositors agree voluntarily for such a conversion.
(5) The bank shall maintain CRR / SLR on the restructured liabilities.

irrelevant.action_point: The Perpetual Debt Instrument (PDI) that may be issued as bonds or debentures by an Indian bank shall meet the following terms and conditions to qualify for inclusion in AT1 capital for capital adequacy purposes: (1) The instruments shall be issued by the bank and fully paid in; (2) The amount of PDI to be raised shall be decided by the Board of Directors of a bank; (3) While complying with minimum Tier 1 of 7 per cent of RWAs, a bank cannot admit, PDI together with PNCPS in AT1 capital, more than 1.5 per cent of RWAs; (4) The PDIs shall be perpetual; (5) The interest payable shall be either at a fixed rate or at a floating rate referenced to a market determined rupee interest benchmark rate; (6) PDIs shall not have any ‘put option’ but may have a ‘call option’ after a minimum of five years, subject to prior RBI approval and conditions ensuring no expectation of call is created and capital position remains strong post-call; (7) Principal may be repaid only with prior RBI approval under specific conditions; (8) The bank shall have full discretion at all times to cancel coupon payments, which shall not be an event of default. Coupons shall be paid out of ‘distributable items’ and shall not be cumulative; (9) The instrument shall not contribute to liabilities exceeding assets in an insolvency test; (10) PDIs shall have principal loss absorption through either conversion to common shares or a write-down mechanism at a pre-specified trigger point; (11) Neither the bank nor a related party shall purchase the instrument, nor shall the bank fund its purchase or grant advances against it; (12) The instrument shall not have features that hinder re-capitalisation; (13) All instances of non-payment of coupon and non-exercise of call option shall be notified to DoR and DoS of the Reserve Bank; (14) The claims of investors shall be superior to equity and PNCPS, but subordinated to depositors, general creditors, and subordinated debt; (15) Investment by FIIs and NRIs is subject to specified limits; (16) A bank may issue PDIs in foreign currency or rupee denominated bonds overseas subject to FEMA guidelines and a limit of 1.5 per cent of RWAs for foreign currency issues; (17) The amount raised will not attract CRR / SLR requirements; (18) A bank issuing PDIs shall submit a report to DoR as per Annex II; (19) A bank's investment in PDIs of other banks is subject to a 10 per cent ceiling of its total regulatory capital and cross-holding limits; (20) The amount raised shall be classified under ‘Schedule 4 – Borrowings’; (21) A foreign bank in India may raise Head Office (HO) borrowings for AT1 capital subject to similar terms and additional conditions regarding maturity, interest rate, tax, documentation, disclosure, and hedging; (22) A bank issuing PDIs to retail investors must obtain a specific sign-off, clearly state the differences from fixed deposits, and explain the loss absorbency features.

An AIFI shall compute and report Gross Advances, Gross NPAs, Net Advances and Net NPAs in the format prescribed in Part A. The computation shall be as follows:
1. Gross Advances shall be the sum of Standard Advances and Gross NPAs. For this purpose, ‘Gross Advances' mean all outstanding loans and advances including advances for which refinance has been received but excluding rediscounted bills, and advances written off at Head Office level (Technical write off).
2. Gross NPAs are defined as the principal dues of NPAs plus Funded Interest Term Loan (FITL) where the corresponding contra credit is parked in Sundries Account (Interest Capitalization - Restructured Accounts), in respect of NPA Accounts.
3. Gross NPAs as a percentage of Gross Advances shall be calculated as (Gross NPAs / Gross Advances).
4. For calculating Net Advances and Net NPAs, the following shall be deducted: (i) Provisions held in the case of NPA Accounts as per asset classification (including additional Provisions for NPAs at higher than prescribed rates), (ii) DICGC / ECGC claims received and held pending adjustment, (iii) Part payment received and kept in Suspense Account or any other similar account, and (iv) Balance in Sundries Account (Interest Capitalization - Restructured Accounts), in respect of NPA Accounts.
5. Net Advances shall be calculated as Gross Advances minus the total deductions specified in point 4.
6. Net NPAs shall be calculated as Gross NPAs minus the total deductions specified in point 4.
7. Net NPAs as a percentage of Net Advances shall be calculated as (Net NPAs / Net Advances).

**B.8 Guarantees on behalf of Share and Stock Brokers/ Commodity Brokers**
The bank issuing guarantees on behalf of share and stock brokers in favour of stock exchanges in lieu of security deposit, shall do so, to the extent it is acceptable in the form of bank guarantee as laid down by stock exchanges. The bank may also issue guarantees in lieu of margin requirements as per stock exchange regulations. The bank shall obtain a minimum margin of 50 per cent while issuing such guarantees. A minimum cash margin of 25 per cent (within the above margin of 50 per cent) shall be maintained in respect of such guarantees issued by the bank. The above minimum margin of 50 per cent and minimum cash margin requirement of 25 per cent (within the margin of 50 per cent) will also apply to guarantees issued by banks on behalf of commodity brokers in favour of the commodity exchanges, registered with Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI), in lieu of margin requirements as per the commodity exchange regulations. The bank shall assess the requirement of each applicant and observe usual and necessary safeguards including the exposure ceilings.

B.8 Display of Unclaimed Deposits and Search Facility
A bank shall host the details of unclaimed deposits {only name, address (without pin code) and Unclaimed Deposit Reference Number (UDRN)}, which have been transferred to DEA Fund of RBI on its website, which shall be updated regularly, at least on a monthly basis. A bank which does not have its own website shall make available the above list of unclaimed deposits in its branches. The database hosted on the website shall provide a search option to enable the public to search for their unclaimed deposits using name in combination with the address of the account holder / entity. Upon a successful search, details of unclaimed deposits shall be displayed in a format comprising account holder’s name(s), his / her address (without pincode) and UDRN only. In case such accounts are not in the name of individuals, the search input and result should include names of individuals authorised to operate the accounts. In the case of a bank under liquidation, during the pendency of the liquidation proceedings, if any claim is received from depositors whose deposits were covered by DICGC insurance at the time of transfer to the Depositor Education and Awareness Fund, the Fund shall pay to the liquidator, an amount equal to the amount that could have been claimed from DICGC with respect to such deposits, and with respect to all other amounts paid by the liquidator towards the amounts transferred to the Fund, whether insured by DICGC or not, the Fund shall reimburse the liquidator. The depositor has to approach the Liquidator of the bank for claim and the Liquidator shall settle the claim as per the following procedure:
(1) Scenario 1: Claim on Deposits Covered by DICGC - If the deposits of a customer / depositor were covered by DICGC insurance at the time of transfer to the DEA Fund, then the Liquidator can claim an amount equivalent to what could have been claimed from DICGC, and then make payment to the depositor. If the above deposit amount is more than the insurance cover of DICGC, then the Liquidator shall claim the amount in excess of DICGC insurance cover only on reimbursement basis i.e., the Liquidator shall pay such amount to the depositor subject to meeting all the applicable requirements and thereafter submit a claim to DEA Fund for reimbursement.
(i) Illustration 1 (DICGC Insurance Cover is up to ₹5 lakh): A customer / depositor had a deposit claim of ₹4 lakh in a bank (including accrued interest), which is now under liquidation. The deposit was insured by DICGC at the time when the said unclaimed deposit was transferred to the Fund. Now, if the customer / depositor claims the same during the liquidation process, the following steps shall be followed: (a) The customer / depositor / legal heir submits a claim for their deposit to the liquidator. (b) Liquidator raises an equivalent claim of ₹4 lakh from the Fund along with necessary supporting documents (c) The Fund will pay an amount equal to the insured deposit to the Liquidator. (In this case, i.e., ₹4 lakh since DICGC insurance cover is available up to ₹5 lakh) (d) The Liquidator, after receiving the amount from the Fund, will pay to the customer / depositor i.e., ₹4 lakh.
(ii) Illustration 2 (DICGC Insurance Cover is up to ₹5 lakh): A customer / depositor had a deposit claim of ₹6 lakh in a bank (including accrued interest), which is now under liquidation. The deposit was insured by DICGC at the time when the unclaimed deposit of the customer / depositor was transferred to the Fund. Now, if the customer / depositor claims the same during the liquidation process, the following steps shall be followed: (a) The customer / depositor / legal heir submits a claim for their deposit to the liquidator. (b) Liquidator raises an equivalent claim of ₹6 lakh from the Fund along with necessary supporting documents. (c) The Fund shall pay an amount equal to the insured deposit to the Liquidator. (In this case, i.e., ₹5 lakh, since DICGC insurance cover is available up to ₹5 lakh) (d) For the remaining amount (i.e., ₹1 lakh) the Liquidator shall make the payment to depositor subject to meeting all the applicable requirements and then claim for the same from the Fund by way of reimbursement.
(2) Scenario 2: Claim on Deposits not Covered by DICGC - In respect of deposits not covered by DICGC at the time of transfer to Fund, the payment to the Liquidator by the Fund shall be made only on reimbursement basis (i.e., the Liquidator can only seek as a reimbursement after settling the amount to the customer / depositor) as mentioned in Illustration 2 above.

irrelevant.action_point:
Urban Co-operative Banks (UCBs) must provide a Key Facts Statement (KFS) to all prospective borrowers for retail and MSME term loans using the following mandatory format and disclosing all specified information:

**Part 1 (Interest rate and fees/charges)**
1.  **Loan proposal/ account No. and Type of Loan**: Disclose the loan proposal or account number and the type of loan.
2.  **Sanctioned Loan amount (in Rupees)**: Disclose the total sanctioned loan amount in Rupees.
3.  **Disbursal schedule**: Disclose whether the disbursement is in stages or 100% upfront. If disbursement is stage-wise, the clause of the loan agreement containing relevant details must be mentioned.
4.  **Loan term (year/months/days)**: Disclose the loan term in years, months, or days.
5.  **Instalment details**: Disclose the type of instalments, number of Equated Periodic Instalments (EPIs), the EPI amount in Rupees, and the commencement date of repayment post-sanction.
6.  **Interest rate (%) and type**: Disclose the interest rate as a percentage and specify its type (fixed, floating, or hybrid).
7.  **Additional Information for Floating rate of interest**: For floating rate loans, disclose the Reference Benchmark, Benchmark rate (%), Spread (%), Final rate (%), Reset periodicity in months (for fixed resets, other than on account of changes in credit profile), and the impact of a 25 bps change in the final rate on both the EPI amount (₹) and the number of EPIs.
8.  **Fee/ Charges**: Disclose all fees and charges, which may be presented net of taxes like GST, under two categories: 'Payable to UCB' and 'Payable to a third party through UCB'. For each charge, specify if it is one-time or recurring, the amount (in ₹) or percentage (%), and the frequency for recurring charges. This must cover at least: (i) Processing fees, (ii) Insurance charges, (iii) Valuation fees, and (iv) Any other applicable charges.
9.  **Annual Percentage Rate (APR) (%)**: Disclose the Annual Percentage Rate, calculated as per the illustration in paragraph 256(3)(i) of the Reserve Bank of India (Urban Co-operative Banks – Responsible Business Conduct) Directions, 2025.
10. **Details of Contingent Charges**: Disclose all contingent charges (in ₹ or %, as applicable), including: (i) Penal charges for delayed payment, (ii) Other penal charges, (iii) Foreclosure charges, if applicable, (iv) Charges for switching loans from floating to fixed rate and vice versa, and (v) Any other applicable charges.

**Part 2 (Other qualitative information)**
1.  **Recovery Agents Clause**: Disclose the specific clause of the loan agreement relating to the engagement of recovery agents.
2.  **Grievance Redressal Clause**: Disclose the specific clause of the loan agreement that details the grievance redressal mechanism.
3.  **Nodal Grievance Redressal Officer Contact**: Disclose the phone number and email ID of the nodal grievance redressal officer. A generic email ID is permissible, provided a response is made within one working day.
4.  **Loan Transfer/Securitisation**: Disclose whether the loan is, or in the future may be, subject to transfer to other regulated entities or securitisation (Yes/No).
5.  **Collaborative Lending Arrangements**: In case of lending under arrangements like co-lending or outsourcing, furnish the following additional details: Name of the originating regulated entity with its funding proportion, Name of the partner regulated entity with its funding proportion, and the Blended rate of interest.
6.  **Digital Loans Disclosures**: In case of digital loans, furnish the following specific disclosures: (i) The cooling-off/look-up period as per the bank’s board-approved policy, during which the borrower will not be charged any penalty on loan prepayment, and (ii) Details of the Lending Service Provider (LSP) acting as a recovery agent who is authorized to approach the borrower.

�� the loan will not mature or be settled in the next 30 days;

**Deposit Accounts**

**Loans**

**CHARGES**
*   Display charges for the following Fee Based Services:
    *   1. Lockers: For different locker types, display charges for 1, 2, and 3-year terms in Metro/Urban/Semi-Urban and Rural locations.

For the computation of Risk-Weighted Assets (RWA) under the Securitisation External Ratings Based Approach (SEC-ERBA) for non-STC securitisation, RBI regulated entities holding securitisation notes must follow this procedure:
1. Determine the Attachment Point (A), Detachment Point (D), and Tranche Thickness (T) for each tranche. The attachment point of one tranche is the detachment point of the next-most junior tranche.
2. For each tranche, identify the applicable 1-year and 5-year base Risk Weights (RW) from the table in Clause 104 based on its external rating and seniority.
3. Adjust the base RW for the tranche's maturity (M) using linear interpolation with the formula: Adjustment in Risk Weight for a maturity equal to M years = RWyear1 + (M-1) * (RWyear5 - RWyear1) / (5-1).
4. For non-senior tranches, further adjust the RW for tranche thickness (T) using the formula: Risk Weight (%) = Risk weight as given in table in para 104 (depending upon senior/non-senior exposure) adjusted for maturity * (1- Minimum (T, 50%)). For senior tranches, no tranche thickness adjustment is required.
5. Calculate the final RWA for the tranche by multiplying the exposure amount by the final calculated Risk Weight.

The policy shall, at a minimum, include: (1) A system of regular review and reporting of material ITEs to the Board; (2) A requirement that the bank addresses risks from ITEs as strictly as it would for a third party; (3) A requirement that terms, conditions, and credit standards of ITEs are substantially the same as those for comparable transactions with non-group entities (arm's length principle); (4) The methodology for a transfer pricing mechanism to ensure compliance with the arm's length principle; (5) Procedures for resolving conflicts of interest from ITEs; (6) Requirements for transparency of third-party dealings associated with group entities, ensuring they are at arm's length; (7) A requirement for the bank's material ITEs to be examined by internal auditors and checked by statutory auditors to ascertain that they: (i) comply with the arm's length principle, (ii) are not detrimental to the bank's interests, (iii) are not for transferring low quality assets, (iv) are not a conduit for inappropriate transfer of capital/income, and (v) if breaching norms, are promptly reported to the RBI; and (8) A mechanism to ensure ITEs do not lead to violation of any regulatory, statutory or taxation laws.

131. Derivative contracts classified as NPA
(1) In respect of derivative contracts classified as NPA, the amount representing unrealized income already booked on accrual basis and taken to 'Profit and Loss a/c' shall be reversed and held in a ‘Suspense Account-Crystallised Receivables' in the same manner as done in the case of overdue advances.
(2) Further, in cases where the derivative contracts provide for more settlements in future, the MTM value will comprise of: (i) crystallised receivables; and (ii) positive or negative MTM in respect of future receivables.
(3) If the derivative contract is not terminated on the overdue receivable remaining unpaid for 90 days, in addition to reversing the crystallised receivable from Profit and Loss Account as stipulated in sub-paragraph (1) above, the positive MTM pertaining to future receivables shall also be reversed from Profit and Loss account to another account styled as 'Suspense Account – Positive MTM’.
(4) The subsequent positive changes in the MTM value shall be credited to the 'Suspense Account – Positive MTM', not to Profit and Loss account.
(5) The subsequent decline in MTM value shall be adjusted against the balance in 'Suspense Account – Positive MTM'. If the balance in this account is not sufficient, the remaining amount may be debited to the P&L Account.
(6) On payment of the overdues in cash, the balance in the ‘Suspense Account-Crystallised Receivables' shall be transferred to the ‘Profit and Loss Account', to the extent payment is received.
(7) If the bank has other derivative exposures on the borrower, the MTMs of other derivative exposures shall also be dealt with / accounted for in the manner as described in this paragraph, subsequent to the crystallised / settlement amount in respect of a particular derivative transaction being treated as NPA.
(8) Similarly, in case a fund-based credit facility extended to a borrower is classified as NPA, the MTMs of all the derivative exposures shall be treated as per this paragraph.

Capital required for supporting credit risk shall be deducted from total capital funds to arrive at capital available for supporting market risk. The calculation methodology is as follows:
1. Determine total capital funds (Tier I capital + Tier II capital).
2. Determine total risk-weighted assets (RWA for credit risk + RWA for market risk).
3. Calculate the minimum capital required to support credit risk as 9% of the RWA for credit risk. This is to be composed of a minimum of 4.5% of RWA for credit risk from Tier I capital and the remainder from Tier II capital.
4. Calculate the capital available to support market risk by subtracting the minimum capital required for credit risk from the total capital funds. This calculation should be performed for each tier of capital separately:
   - Tier I capital available for market risk = Total Tier I capital - Tier I capital required for credit risk.
   - Tier II capital available for market risk = Total Tier II capital - Tier II capital required for credit risk.

irrelevant.action_point: The SPE should meet the following criteria to enable the originator to apply the guidelines on capital adequacy and other aspects as prescribed in these directions with regard to the securitisation exposures assumed by it: (1) Any transaction between the originator and the SPE should be strictly on arm's length basis. (2) The SPE and the trustee should not resemble in name or imply any connection or relationship with the originator of the assets in its title or name. (3) The originator should not have any ownership, proprietary or beneficial interest in the SPE except those specifically permitted under these directions. The originator shall not hold any share capital in the SPE. (4) The originator should not have more than one representative, without veto power, on the board of the SPE provided the board has at least four members and independent directors are in majority. (5) If the SPE is set up as a trust, then: (i) The originator should not exercise control, directly or indirectly, over the SPE and the trustees, and shall not settle the trust deed, if any. (ii) The originator shall not have any ownership, proprietary or beneficial interest in the trustees. (iii) The SPE should be bankruptcy remote and non-discretionary. (iv) The trust deed, if any, should lay down, in detail, the functions to be performed by the trustee, their rights and obligations as well as the rights and obligations of the investors in relation to the securitised assets. The trust deed should not provide for any discretion to the trustee as to the manner of disposal and management or application of the trust property. In order to protect their interests, investors should be empowered in the trust deed to change the trustee at any point of time. (v) The trustee should only perform trusteeship functions in relation to the SPE and should not undertake any other business with the SPE. (vi) A copy of the trust deed, if any, and the accounts and statement of affairs of the SPE should be made available by the originator and/or other lenders, to the RBI, if required to do so. (6) The originator shall not support the losses of the SPE except under the facilities explicitly permitted under these directions and shall also not be liable to meet the recurring expenses of the SPE. (7) The SPE should make it clear to the investors in the securitization notes issued by it that these securitisation notes are not insured and do not represent deposit liabilities of the originator, servicer or trustees.

Ε. Income recognition in special cases
118. Derivative contracts classified as NPA
(1) In respect of derivative contracts classified as NPA, the amount representing unrealized income already booked on accrual basis and taken to 'Profit and Loss a/c' shall be reversed and held in a 'Suspense Account-Crystallised Receivables' in the same manner as done in the case of overdue advances.
(2) Further, in cases where the derivative contracts provide for more settlements in future, the MTM value will comprise of: (i) crystallised receivables; and (ii) positive or negative MTM in respect of future receivables.
(3) If the derivative contract is not terminated on the overdue receivable remaining unpaid for 90 days, in addition to reversing the crystallised receivable from Profit and Loss Account as stipulated at sub-paragraph (1), the positive MTM pertaining to future receivables shall also be reversed from Profit and Loss Account to another account styled as 'Suspense Account – Positive MTM'.
(4) The subsequent positive changes in the MTM value shall be credited to the 'Suspense Account – Positive MTM', not to P&L Account.
(5) The subsequent decline in MTM value shall be adjusted against the balance in 'Suspense Account – Positive MTM'. If the balance in this account is not sufficient, the remaining amount may be debited to the P&L Account.
(6) On payment of the overdues in cash, the balance in the 'Suspense Account-Crystallised Receivables' shall be transferred to the ‘Profit and Loss Account', to the extent payment is received.
(7) If the bank has other derivative exposures on the borrower, the MTMs of other derivative exposures shall also be dealt with / accounted for in the manner as described in this paragraph, subsequent to the crystallised / settlement amount in respect of a particular derivative transaction being treated as NPA.
(8) Similarly, in case a fund-based credit facility extended to a borrower is classified as NPA, the MTMs of all the derivative exposures should be treated as per this paragraph.

- Technology and payment system / transaction

**IV Proceedings, if any, against the director**
A If the director is a member of a professional association / body, details of disciplinary action, if any, pending or commenced or resulting in conviction in the past against her / him or whether she / he has been banned from entry of at any profession / occupation at any time.

irrelevant.action_point: The aforesaid conditions shall, mutatis mutandis, be applicable to the subsidiaries of a bank in so far as they are not contradictory to specific regulations of RBI or SEBI, governing their operations. The conditions are: (1) PMS shall be in the nature of investment consultancy / management, for a fee, entirely at the customer's risk without guaranteeing, either directly or indirectly, a pre-determined return; (2) The fee charged shall be independent of the return to the client; (3) The funds shall not be accepted for portfolio management for a period less than one year. In the case of placement of funds for portfolio management by the same client on more than one occasion, on a continuous basis, each such placement shall be treated as a separate account and each such placement shall be for a minimum period of one year; (4) Funds accepted for portfolio management from the clients, shall not be entrusted to another bank for management; (5) Portfolio funds shall not be deployed for lending in call money / bills market, and lending to / placement with corporate bodies; (6) A bank providing PMS shall maintain client wise account / record of funds accepted and investments made there against, and all credits (including realised interest, dividend, etc.) and debits (tax deducted at source in respect of interest / dividend on securities) shall reflect in such account. The account holder shall be entitled to get a statement of his portfolio account; (7) A bank's own investments and investments belonging to the PMS clients shall be kept distinct from each other. Transactions between the bank's investment account and portfolio account shall be strictly at market rates; (8) A bank shall maintain a ‘Clients' Portfolio Account' in its general ledger, reflecting the funds received by it for portfolio management on a day-to-day basis. The balance lying in this account (i.e. undeployed funds, if any, from this account) shall be treated as outside borrowings of the bank and it shall maintain cash reserve ratio / statutory liquidity ratio on such funds. The bank's liability to its clients in respect of funds accepted by it for portfolio management shall be properly reflected in the bank's published books of accounts; (9) There shall be a clear functional separation of trading and back-office functions relating to banks' own investment accounts and PMS clients' accounts; and (10) PMS clients' accounts shall be subjected by banks to a separate audit by external auditors.

G. Conditions to be satisfied by the special purpose entity
30. The SPE should meet the following criteria to enable the originator to apply the guidelines on capital adequacy and other aspects as prescribed in these directions with regard to the securitisation exposures assumed by it:
a. Any transaction between the originator and the SPE should be strictly on arm's length basis.
b. The SPE and the trustee should not resemble in name or imply any connection or relationship with the originator of the assets in its title or name.
c. The originator should not have any ownership, proprietary or beneficial interest in the SPE except those specifically permitted under these directions. The originator should not hold any share capital in the SPE.
d. The originator should not have more than one representative, without veto power, on the board of the SPE provided the board has at least four members and independent directors are in majority.
e. If the SPE is set up as a trust, then:
i. The originator shall not exercise control, directly or indirectly, over the SPE and the trustees, and shall not settle the trust deed, if any.
ii. The originator shall not have any ownership, proprietary or beneficial interest in the trustees.
iii. The SPE should be bankruptcy remote and non-discretionary.
iv. The trust deed, if any, should lay down, in detail, the functions to be performed by the trustee, their rights and obligations as well as the rights and obligations of the investors in relation to the securitised assets. The trust deed should not provide for any discretion to the trustee as to the manner of disposal and management or application of the trust property. In order to protect their interests, investors should be empowered in the trust deed to change the trustee at any point of time.
v. The trustee should only perform trusteeship functions in relation to the SPE and should not undertake any other business with the SPE.
vi. A copy of the trust deed, if any, and the accounts and statement of affairs of the SPE should be made available by the originator and/or other lenders, to the RBI, if required to do so.
f. The originator shall not support the losses of the SPE except under the facilities explicitly permitted under these directions and shall also not be liable to meet the recurring expenses of the SPE.
g. The SPE should make it clear to the investors in the securitisation notes issued by it that these securitisation notes are not insured and that they do not represent deposit liabilities of the originator, servicer or trustees.

irrelevant.action_point: A UCB shall at a minimum provide the relevant details in respect of entries in the accounts as illustrated below: For debit entries related to 'Payment to third parties', the details shall include (i) Name of the payee, (ii) Mode – Transfer, clearing, inter-branch, RTGS/ NEFT, cash, cheque (number), and (iii) Name of the transferee bank, if the payment is made through clearing/ inter-branch transaction/ RTGS/ NEFT. For debit entries related to 'Payment to ‘self’', the details shall include (i) Indicate “Self” as payee and (ii) Name of the ATM/ branch if the payment is made by ATM/ another branch. For debit entries related to 'Issuance of drafts/ pay orders/ any other payment instrument', the details shall include (i) Name of the payee (in brief/ acronym) and (ii) Name of the drawee bank/ branch/ service branch. For debit entries related to 'Bank charges', the details shall include (i) Nature of the charges – fee/ commission/ penalty etc. and (ii) Reasons for the charges, in brief – e.g. return of cheque (number), commission/ fee on draft issued/ remittance (draft number), cheque collection charge (number), issuance of cheque book, SMS alerts, ATM fees, additional cash withdrawals, etc. For debit entries related to 'Reversal of wrong credits', the details shall include (i) Date of the original credit entry reversed and (ii) Reasons for reversal, in brief. For debit entries related to 'Recovery of instalments of a loan/ interest on loan', the details shall include (i) Loan account number and (ii) Name of the Loan account holder. For debit entries related to 'Creation of term deposit/ recurring deposit', the details shall include (i) Term Deposit/ Recurring Deposit Account/ Receipt number and (ii) Name of the Term Deposit/ Recurring Deposit Account holder. For debit entries related to 'Transactions at POS', the details shall include (i) Transaction date, time and identification number and (ii) Location of the POS. For any other debit entries, adequate details on the same lines as mentioned above shall be provided. In case of single debit in account with multiple credits, the payee name/ account number/ branch/ bank shall not be recorded; however, the fact of “multiple payees” will be indicated. For credit entries related to 'Cash deposit', the details shall include (i) Indicate that it is a “cash deposit” and (ii) Name of the depositor – self/ third party. For credit entries related to 'Receipt from third parties', the details shall include (i) Name of the remitter/ transferor, (ii) Mode – Transfer, inter-branch, RTGS/ NEFT, cash, etc., and (iii) Name of the transferor bank, if the payment is received through inter-branch transaction, RTGS/ NEFT. For credit entries related to 'Proceeds of clearing/ collection/ draft etc. paid', the details shall include (i) Name of the draft issuing bank and (ii) Date and number of the cheque/ draft. For credit entries related to 'Reversal of wrong debits (including charges)', the details shall include (i) Date of the original debit entry reversed and (ii) Reasons for reversal, in brief. For credit entries related to 'Interest on deposits', the details shall include (i) Mention if it is interest paid on the Savings Account/ Term Deposit and (ii) Mention the respective Term Deposit Account/ Receipt Number if it is interest paid on Term Deposit(s). For credit entries related to 'Maturity proceeds of term deposit/ recurring deposit', the details shall include (i) Name of the Term Deposit/ Recurring Deposit holder, (ii) Term Deposit/ Recurring Deposit account/ receipt number, and (iii) Date of maturity. For credit entries related to 'Loan proceeds', the details shall include the Loan account number. For any other credit entries, adequate details shall be provided.

irrelevant.action_point:
G. Conditions to be satisfied by the special purpose entity
28. The SPE should meet the following criteria to enable the originator to apply the guidelines on capital adequacy and other aspects as prescribed in these directions with regard to the securitisation exposures assumed by it:
(1) Any transaction between the originator and the SPE should be strictly on arm's length basis.
(2) The SPE and the trustee should not resemble in name or imply any connection or relationship with the originator of the assets in its title or name.
(3) The originator should not have any ownership, proprietary or beneficial interest in the SPE except those specifically permitted under these directions. The originator shall not hold any share capital in the SPE.
(4) The originator should not have more than one representative, without veto power, on the board of the SPE provided the board has at least four members and independent directors are in majority.
(5) If the SPE is set up as a trust, then:
(i) The originator should not exercise control, directly or indirectly, over the SPE and the trustees, and shall not settle the trust deed, if any.
(ii) The originator shall not have any ownership, proprietary or beneficial interest in the trustees.
(iii) The SPE should be bankruptcy remote and non-discretionary.
(iv) The trust deed, if any, should lay down, in detail, the functions to be performed by the trustee, their rights and obligations as well as the rights and obligations of the investors in relation to the securitised assets. The trust deed should not provide for any discretion to the trustee as to the manner of disposal and management or application of the trust property. In order to protect their interests, investors should be empowered in the trust deed to change the trustee at any point of time.
(v) The trustee should only perform trusteeship functions in relation to the SPE and should not undertake any other business with the SPE.
(vi) A copy of the trust deed, if any, and the accounts and statement of affairs of the SPE should be made available by the originator and/or other lenders, to the RBI, if required to do so.
(6) The originator shall not support the losses of the SPE except under the facilities explicitly permitted under these directions and shall also not be liable to meet the recurring expenses of the SPE.
(7) The SPE should make it clear to the investors in the securitization notes issued by it that these securitisation notes are not insured and do not represent deposit liabilities of the originator, servicer or trustees.
irrelevant.circular_name: Reserve Bank of India (Small Finance Banks – Securitisation Transactions) Directions, 2025

(2) The SPE and the trustee should not resemble in name or imply any connection or relationship with the originator of the assets in its title or name.
(3) The originator should not have any ownership, proprietary or beneficial interest in the SPE except those specifically permitted under these directions. The originator shall not hold any share capital in the SPE.
(4) The originator should not have more than one representative, without veto power, on the board of the SPE provided the board has at least four members and independent directors are in majority.
(5) If the SPE is set up as a trust, then:
(i) The originator should not exercise control, directly or indirectly, over the SPE and the trustees, and shall not settle the trust deed, if any.
(ii) The originator shall not have any ownership, proprietary or beneficial interest in the trustees.
(iii) The SPE should be bankruptcy remote and non-discretionary.
(iv) The trust deed, if any, should lay down, in detail, the functions to be performed by the trustee, their rights and obligations as well as the rights and obligations of the investors in relation to the securitised assets. The trust deed should not provide for any discretion to the trustee as to the manner of disposal and management or application of the trust property. In order to protect their interests, investors should be empowered in the trust deed to change the trustee at any point of time.
(v) The trustee should only perform trusteeship functions in relation to the SPE and should not undertake any other business with the SPE.
(vi) A copy of the trust deed, if any, and the accounts and statement of affairs of the SPE should be made available by the originator and/or other lenders, to the RBI, if required to do so.
(6) The originator shall not support the losses of the SPE except under the facilities explicitly permitted under these directions and shall also not be liable to meet the recurring expenses of the SPE.
(7) The SPE should make it clear to the investors in the securitization notes issued by it that these securitisation notes are not insured and do not represent deposit liabilities of the originator, servicer or trustees.

irrelevant.action_point:
**B. Authorisation, Accountability, and Oversight**
In addition to adhering to the requirements stipulated in subparagraphs (i) to (v) of paragraph 18 of these Directions, which state that a bank shall ensure that: (i) all relevant laws, regulations, rules, guidelines and conditions of approval, licensing or registration have been considered when performing due diligence in relation to outsourcing; (ii) outsourcing, whether the service provider is located in India or outside, does not impede RBI in carrying out its supervisory functions and objectives, or diminish the ability of a bank to fulfil its obligations to the regulator / supervisor; (iii) outsourcing, whether the service provider is located in India or outside, does not impede or interfere with the ability of a bank to effectively oversee and manage its activities, and fulfil its obligations; (iv) outsourcing would not result in the compromise or weakening of a bank's internal control, business conduct, or reputation; and (v) the service provider employs the same high standard of care in performing the services as would be employed by the bank, if the activities were conducted within the bank and not outsourced; a bank shall ensure that the service provider, if not a group company, shall not be owned or controlled by any director, or key managerial personnel, or approver of the outsourcing arrangement of the bank, or their relatives. The terms ‘control', 'director', 'key managerial personnel', and 'relative' shall have the same meaning as assigned under the Companies Act, 2013 and the Rules framed thereunder from time to time. Provided that an exception to the above requirement may be made with the approval of Board or a Committee of the Board, followed by appropriate disclosure, oversight and monitoring of such arrangements.
